resp:

Looking through the table's data, I see a few entries with "ferrari" in the constructor column. Let me note those down. There are two such rows: Michael Schumacher and Eddie Irvine. Both have "ferrari" as their constructor.

Now, the claim mentions both first and second positions at the finish line. So I need to check what position each of these drivers ended up in. The columns related here would be "laps" and "grid," but actually, the relevant column is "grid" because it shows the starting position, and "time / retired" might indicate if someone finished or not. Wait, no—the positions at the finish line are usually the same as the grid positions unless there's a change due to retirements or other issues.

Looking at Michael Schumacher's row: he started in position 4 (grid) and completed 72 laps. So he ended up finishing 4th. Eddie Irvine also started in position 6 but finished with +1 lap, which might mean he didn't complete all laps? Wait, the "time / retired" column shows "+ 1 lap," which I think means he lost a lap, so maybe he finished in 7th place because he started 6th and lost one lap. Hmm, that doesn't add up.

Wait, actually, if someone loses a lap, their finishing position is one less than their starting position? Or does it mean they didn't complete the race, hence not counted as finishing? I'm a bit confused here. Let me think again.

In racing, when a driver loses laps due to penalties or issues, they might be classified as "Did Not Finish" (DNF). But in this table, it's just noted as "+ 1 lap," which could mean they didn't complete the race. So if someone starts in position 6 and has "+ 1 lap," they might not have finished, hence no finishing position.

Wait, looking at the data: Michael Schumacher started in position 4 with "ferrari" and completed 72 laps, so he finished in 4th place. Eddie Irvine had a "+ 1 lap" which probably means he didn't finish, so he wouldn't have taken the second position. Then, who is in second?

Looking through the constructors: McLaren-Mercedes has David Coulthard starting in position 2 and completed 72 laps, so he finished 2nd. Ferrari's Michael Schumacher is 4th. So only one Ferrari driver (Michael Schumacher) took a position at the finish line, not both first and second.

So the claim that "ferrari contractor take both the first and second position" would be false because only Michael Schumacher finished in the top two for Ferrari, actually finishing 4th, while Eddie Irvine didn't finish. So there are no Ferraris in both first and second positions at the finish line.

